reviewText: I have been very pleased with this purchase. Something that struck me immediately when I first did this workout was the music.  I love studio dance classes with live African drumming, and although the drum music Jennifer uses in the warm up does not appear to be live, it certainly has that feel. For me, music is much more motivating than "encouraging words" from the the instructor, and that music component is often missing in exercise DVDs.  Often, the music is too quiet to be motivating, even if good selections were made.  The production on this DVD is perfect as far as the sound goes.  The music is loud enough, yet we can still hear Jennifer perfectly well.  Yeah!  The workout works the legs particularly well and has a nice cool down stretch at the end.  To get a good ab workout, you really need to focus on the moves to get the most you can out of it.
summary: Finally, a good fusion DVD with quality music!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Pros:- I was sore the next day in my obliques/abs.- The DVD is a good length, and lets you choose which segments of the workout you want to do.- The instructor was pretty good.- She shows you modifications to make the exercises easier if you need it.- I felt more flexible after doing this workout.- I enjoyed this workout.Cons:- Although normally I like stretching, the post-workout stretching was not as good as I've seen in other fitness DVDs.General comments:First, I highly recommend you get a yoga mat in order to do the exercises in this DVD. Second, the instructor also uses small hand weights (3 to 5 lbs) in this DVD, but not very much (you'll probably be fine without them). Third, this DVD has some pilates and yoga-like moves. It's different from my other ballet fitness DVD (it's the one by Element). I like both DVDs, and they're different enough that I'm glad I own both.To summarize, I highly recommend this DVD.
summary: Sore the next day! Great workout!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is my first work out by Jennifer Galardi and I was very pleased.  I do many types of workouts as I am a daily exerciser and I really like a wide array of different workouts to choose from.  I have done pilates, dance and yoga before, but never in such a nice little workout!  The workout is in 5 sections:Warm up-approx 13 minutes and this is concentrated mainly on plies (knee bends).  She does use ballet terminology as "your feet are in 2nd position" or "arms are in 5th position", but no need to know what this means, just follow along if you are not familiar with ballet.  The movements are easy to follow, so no worries.Stength-approx 13 minutes and this section uses light weights for arm exercises.  No need for heavy weights here.  It looks like they are using about 3 lb. but as you need to you can increase if you would like more resistance.Balance-approx. 14 minutes-this section is based more in yoga and you will do the chair pose, plank, downward dog, tricep pushups and will relax back into child's pose.Floor Barre-approx. 10 minutes-These exercises do not require a dancer's barre as they are modified for the mat.  These exercises are more Pilates based with moves like the roll-up and rolling like a ball.Stretch-13 minutes of heaven-great stretches based in yoga, including the pigeon, relaxing forward bends, spinal twists, etc.  Extremely relaxing and rejuvinating.I really enjoyed this workout and know that this will definitely be in my weekly rotation.  The instructor had good form, controlled moves, which are great for core stability and she has a pleasant personality without being over-the-top.I will caution, if you are looking for a cardio workout-this is not it.  If you are looking for all dance exercises, also not for you, if you want a slower work-out with controlled movements good for toning and creating lean muscles, this IS the workout for you.  The fusion between the different types of exercise is a winner in my book.  Give it a go if you are up for something a little out of the ordinary!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was my first ballet style workout. I'm no ballerina, so I have no idea if the instructor is giving "real" ballet instructions. I don't care for the "warm-up", the dancing is too fast for me to try to keep good form (I'm afraid I'll get hurt) and keep up w/ her. I enjoy all the other workouts though. One thing I didn't like was at the end of the "Stretch" segment she does a yoga thing w/ her legs crossed, hands on knees w/ the "O" shaped hands & holds this for a long while, seems like a waste of time for a workout video. I can sit still in silence anytime by myself, I get workout videos to have someone instruct me on "exercising" not sitting. But other than that I really liked it.

reviewText: This is an incredible ballet workout, I find myself doing this one the most. It really deliver results! A really nice change from high impact but dont let that fool ya! You will get results!

reviewText: This is a very graceful, relaxing, fun, and effective total body workout with beautiful and yet challenging bellet-yoga movements.  This workout really helps me relax, stretch and strengthen my body and soul.  I love the beautiful background music too which is very important.  I have about 30+  workout DVDs including yoga, cardio, weights, and this is one of the most enjoyable ones that I do not get bored of.  I absolutely adore this DVD.  Jennifer Garlardi is great!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I also own Jennifer's 10-min. workout and so when I bought this, I expected real ballet and maybe some actual dance steps with flowing, inspirational classical music.  What I got was alot of plies and porta bras done to an African drum beat or a piano-driven track that sounds like telephone hold muzac. Occasionally, you hear this rhythmic pneumatic hissing sound that goes like this; " tsss-ch-pahhh!" I can't tell if it's supposed to be part of the soundtrack or it's some sweaty guy panting in the background.  Whatever it is, it's annoying.  It got on my nerves so much I finally shelved this DVD and made up my own ballet workout using Rachmananov, Strauss and Chopin.  Too bad because I really wanted a true ballet workout that I could do at home and also enjoy.  A word of caution to those with no training or balance: be careful of the grand plies she does without a barre.  These could actually hurt you if you are not centered in your core.  Use a chair if you feel off balance.  Suprised she didn't suggest that.
summary: Drumbeats and Plies!  Where's the Ballet???
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was tempted to give it a three rating but figure some of my rating is based on personal preference.  I had used the stretch segment a handful of times and liked that but then finally decided to give the entire DVD a try.  I stopped the DVD about 33 minutes into it.1) Except for my calves and feet, I really did not feel like I was getting a good workout.  I tend to be tight in my hips so found I had to reduce the range of motion just slightly for the fast paced second position plies.  I had no burn at all from the thigh work.  For me, I much prefer the isometric work with barre inspired workouts like Core Fusion, Pure Barre, Bar Method, and even Rockin Models!2) The yoga section was pretty easy and I actually got bored with it.3) She mentioned on the video a few times a cardio impact but this wasn't cardio for me at all.All in all, I just did not feel like I was getting a decent workout and I was bored.I'm surprised that Collage Video rates this as intermediate/advanced. I would think as long as someone doesn't have bad knees, I would rate this as beginner/intermediate.  If you have tricky knees you may have problems with all of the fast paced plies.
summary: Just could not get into this one
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jennifer's ballet inspired workout is split into 5 mini workouts so you can do as much or as little as you like - though I recommend always doing the warm up (1st workout) and stretch (5th & last workout) to avoid injury.The ballet like moves are relatively simple and heaps of fun for an uncoordinated non dancer like myself - though there wouldn't be enough ballet for professional-type dancers.This is the first 60 minute (in total) workout that I have ever completed all the way through and keep coming back for more as I work to improve my form and flexibility. Jennifer is great at cueing so you won't have to keep reaching for the rewind button. The music is great and the workout in general is challenging for someone working to improve their upper body strength and flexibility (not to mention toning their legs). The first 4 work outs will leave your legs shaking and your arms tired and you cursing working out - but the extended stretch session is so lovely and calming - you forget the pain and want to do it all over again very soon! I swear my little sugar belly feels smaller/more pulled in everytime I do this workout.I am very loyal to my Ellen Barrett workouts but Jennifer Galardi's Ballet Body is a firm favourite. I have searched for JG's other workouts but none appear to be in the style of Ballet Body - I wish she would do more DVDs like this one, it's great - two thumbs up!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a wonderful ballet workout. It feels just like a ballet class! It has five segments that you can do separately , all together , or mix and match. Jennifer's pleasant and encouraging voice  keeps the video lighthearted even during the harder exercises.There are modifications for almost every exercise , both to make them easier and harder , so they would work for a wider range of fitness. The exercises are graceful and beautiful as well as physically and mentally challenging. You can feel your posture and strength improving after just a few times. My daughters and I  keep going back to this one --- It was definitely worth purchasing!!!!!!

reviewText: I enjoy dance-based workouts and loved Jennifer's Hip Hop Party DVD, so I decided to get this for more targeted conditioning using balletic exercise.  All I can say is wow!  It really is such a feel-good workout.  But still definitely a workout!!  And because Jennifer is a fun teacher, who is nothing like the "exer-bots" on other DVDs, I feel like I'm working out with a friend.  This one is a favorite!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great workout!Items Needed: Mat, light hand weights (strength section)The Warmup: Starts with oblique, arm, back, legs, and shoulder stretches at a slow pace.  Next are plies, squats, torso stretches, and balancing with ballet flavor of course. If you are stiff, the warm up is a workout itself! Jennifer really takes the time to condition the appropriate muscles. She is concise and pleasant in her presentation which makes the tons of squats she sneaks in go by quickly.Strength Section:Plie series, standing ab scoops, squats, and arm exercises with weights, so get ready! Your thighs, calves, and glutes will thank you!Balance and Length:Mini standing arabesques, chair poses, and yoga strengthening rounds this section out leaving you in relaxing child's pose.Floor Barre:Sitting leg extensions, ab work, frogs, roll ups, leg scissors,  and inner thigh lifts. If you have back or neck  issues, be careful with this section.Stretch:Jennifer walks you through maximizing your stretches to target specific areas.  Very thorough.She incorporates pigeon poses, breathing, seated twisting poses, and a total body cooldown with nice relaxing music.This fusion workout of pilates, ballet, and yoga is a standard for your collection! Great job Jennifer! Not overdone, no gimmicks, just perfect execution and beautiful moves that transform your body!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great combination of ballet and yoga from Jennifer here. Simple, but very effective moves. I can feel my arms and legs burning within moments of beginning the workout.I am *very* out of shape, so some of the moves (especially the floor moves) are definitely a work in progress. Had to take a break and/or modify during many of the leg lifts, but I kept plugging through it and can feel myself growing stronger. Some of the ballet moves may be challenging if you lack balance, but they're simple enough that you can hold on to a chair without restricting your movement.Great instruction from Jennifer, as always.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is not a dance class, rather, an enjoyable dance-inspired workout rooted in balletic movement.  Effective toning with some low-impact cardio.The "warm-up" is a plie series that gets the heart pumping, followed by standing abdominals, light weight work, and a series based on single-leg balances partnered with fluid motion in the working leg.  "Floor barre" focuses on the abdominals.  The whole thing is peppered with some yoga (downdog splits, core-plank waves, modified sun salutation).  Nothing new here, but it is difficult to argue when it is fun and effective.The main drawback of the DVD is that you may wish to repeat the first segment to get an effective cardio workout.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you need a relaxing workout--and aren't in the mood for yoga--and also want something that's not too wussy, this is it.  The set is really relaxing, too.  Well thought out, well cued.  Gentle and a little different.

reviewText: i actually bought this for the stretch section. and i'm very glad i did, the other segments are very fun. i'll let the other reviews stand and explain- which is why i put this on my wish list to begin with. i just really like the instructor Jennifer and the stretch segment will be completed alot.

reviewText: I became a fan of Jennifer Galardi after doing one of her shows on Fit TV (All Star Workouts) that is very similar to this DVD.  This type of exercise really gets results without some of the more gruelling "gym rat" exercises.  I particularly like doing ab work without having to do crunches on the floor.  I enjoyed the work so much I did the entire thing (63 minutes) the first day, and only found myself a bit overworked in the "Balance" section, where you move from down-dog to plank position for a while without touching down.The very next day after the workout, my hips felt tighter (after all those plies!), and as always with ballet workouts, I felt more balanced. There's an ease of movement that come from it that's hard to describe but is really a joy.  I highly recommend this DVD, and hope Jen Galardi will do many more like this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay so this was my first true fusion workout.  I have heard the term, but never quite understood what it meant.  I wanted to incorporate more ballet into my routines, so I was excited to try this workout.  It did not disappoint.  Normally, I’m a heavy weight training and intense cardio workout person, but I wanted to mix things up.Why I enjoyed this workout:* Jennifer.  She is so sweet and looks just like the girl next door.  I love her style and her teaching way.  I didn’t have any trouble following her, like some of the other reviewers did.* The flowing movements.  I love plies; or rather I should say that I have a love/hate relationship with them.  I love how they help shape my legs; I ‘hate’ how hard they can be and how they make my muscles burn.I didn’t find this workout all that hard.  I use it as a second, evening workout, or during my rest week.  After I am done, my muscles feel gently worked and stretched.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I do like this workout overall, she does typical ballet moves that work you somewhat. However, I feel that she moves pretty quickly through things, not giving slightly uncoordinated people a chance to figure out the steps. Also, I found it a little odd that she uses weights in part of the workout because in a true ballet workout, you are not using weights. You are using your arm movements and holding them up alot which is weight in itself, to develop those pretty arms. But that's a minor complaint. Also, she seems to use a bit of yoga in this DVD as well. That's ok, but I am not into yoga and I felt she could've kept the whole workout true ballet exercise, but once again, a minor complaint. Had I read the full description, I would have known that she incorporates yoga, pilates and ballet all together but I somehow missed that. I may not have bought it based on that but I'm not unhappy that I did and I'll do the workout again. However, if you are looking for a true ballet workout or to seriously get a dancers body I suggestKari Anderson: Reach - Upbeat Toning & Flexibility for a Dancer's Bodyor elseElement: Ballet Conditioning. Those are very good ballet workouts that will leave you feeling like a dancer. Kari's is more focused on balance and flexibility and strength, While "Element" is totally focused on ballet exercises like lots of plies, releve's, tendu's, degages, etc. My legs and arms are screaming halfway through the "Element" DVD, maybe sooner. With Kari's I can do the whole workout and feel very much worked out but I can finish it. It's my favorite of the three. Those two DVD's don't require much room to do which is nice, and both have nice music. Jennifer Gallardi's requires a little more room to move around. I kept kicking walls in my bedroom which is small so I'll have to take it to the living room. Also, the instructors in the Reach and Element DVD's have been in ballet dance companies and their exercises are based on many years of experience. You finish knowing you did a true ballet workout. No weights, no yoga. Kari Anderson has good stretching and flexiblility sections. But still, Jennifer Galardi's DVD is pretty good & worth buying. It's just that knowing the other two are better, I can't give this 5 stars or recommend it above those two. If you can get all three, though, go for it.
summary: Nice workout but she goes a little fast
Title: N/A

reviewText: This workout indeed does combine low-impact standing/balance work with mild weight strengthening, yoga, some Pilates, and stretching. There is also a long stretch segment at the end, which I think many would enjoy (I thought it was a bit too long and would have liked instead more time dedicated to balance and standing work, but that's just my opinion). The movements are not particularly creative, as most are derivatives of other forms (yoga, Pilates). The ballet-conditioning warm-up section is good, and shows the basics of ballet movement being executed well. The music is actually pretty pleasant, and not annoying or cheesy like some exercise dvds tend to have during the workout. There could have been more cardio work involved, but I did break a decent sweat doing the routine. I got a bit impatient at the end (the stretch segment, which is quite long at about 10-13 mins), and so I ended up cutting it off prematurely by about 2 minutes and instead put in a kickboxing dvd so I could fit in about 20 mins of extra pure cardio work to round out the workout. Overall, a good, manageable workout. Jennifer is likable, but impresses me as a bit "air-heady"...she is nevertheless good-natured and enthusiastic, and seems to really enjoy herself during the workout. I would say this workout is worth the money, and is more relaxing if one wishes to experience a less heart-pounding, sweat-drenched workout experience.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I do Jennifer's 10 minute solutions dance off (2 of them) and then follow up with Ballet Body.  I am sweating up a storm.  The warm-up for Ballet Body is not really a warm-up; it actually loosens your body's muscles.  If you need a DVD to loosen up a tight body, then this is it!  I highly recommend it.  I haven't done it long enough to see any results, but you feel invigorated after completing it.  The only segment I did not like is floor barr.  The DVD even has some yoga sequences and vinyanas.  This is an excellent relaxation and stretch DVD.Update: Like the other reviewer, I too didn't like the stretch segment.  I do all the segments except the yoga and the stretching and my body gets hot.  Today, I was freezing and after 30 minutes of this DVD I was burning up.What is really great about this DVD is that I zone out when I do it.  At the beginning there are african drums and in the middle you are doing relavays and other moves to beautiful classical music.  I feel so good about life and myself after doing this DVD.  I use it to break away at work (I have my own office).If you want a toning DVD, a DVD to loosen the muscles, and a DVD to relax the mind--this is the DVD for you.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've only recently discovered ballet/fusion workouts and have been using a few : this one, Jennifer KriesThe Method Pilates - Target SpecificsandBernadette Giorgi: Attitude Ballet & Pilates Fusionand also Ellen Barrett. I've previously done more intense cardio with hip hop, dance and kickboxing and thought it was time to vary my workout.  I have several Jennifer Galardi dance dvds, which I've found excellent, so I was looking forward to this one.  However, I'm rather disappointed.  Though I have no doubt that the moves are effective, I find it dull and I'm just watching the clock wanting it to be over.  It also feels a little long - I know other reviewers love this because you can switch off, however I feel I can't even get engaged to want to do the moves properly.  It's not that I want to be jumping around or kicking/punching something, it's just that the moves feel like reps. As in very repetitious. Also, I have problems  with the yoga part of this workout . I've done some yoga, and many workouts which require you to be in a prolonged plank position and never had any problems,  but I find there's something about the yoga portion here that makes my wrists ache that I have to abandon the poses.Of the ballet/fusion dvds I own, I'd say this one gets the least use and actually I'm tempted to give it away.  I much prefer Jennifer Kries which, though it says it is pilates based, has ballet steps for working out the hips and legs, and my favorite upper limb toning section ever.  That one also has a fair bit of yoga, so it's a great fusion workout.  Bernadette Giorgi who explains the ballet moves wonderfully well and adds variety with a hand held weighted  ball.  Hers is a little slower paced and the floor work is tough.  These are not just ballet workouts though, so if it's just ballet your after, these may not be for you. However if you want to incorporate various disciplines, these  dvds are fabulous.  They are really energising, whereas if I try to do this Ballet Body dvd when I feel tired, I'll just be yawning and struggling.  I will persist though, because  the moves are effective.  It's just not much fun.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This workout is quite challenging for folks, like me, who've remained dormant far too long.  Must remember to not overdo or to get discouraged because you can't keep up; just do what you can and eventually the exercises become a little easier. Definitely a good all-body workout/stretch routine.  Advice:  Keep "pause" button handy.
summary: One almost needs to be in shape beforehand!
